bug.author: yanniszark
bug.summary: Jupyter notebook pod creation fails with 'serviceaccount "jupyter-notebook" not found'
bug.description:
Steps to reproduce:
Clone kubeflow/kubeflow and checkout to commit 58022fb (Mon May 13 14:16:13 2019 -0400). Install Istio from dependencies/istio:
kubectl apply -f dependencies/istio/install/crds.yaml kubectl apply -f dependencies/istio/install/istio-noauth.yaml
cd bootstrap; make build-kfctl-container cd bin and follow the generic guide Get NodePort port of ambassador service, go to http://<node-ip>/<port>. Create a new Notebook, try kubectl describe statefulset and see that it fails with 'serviceaccount "jupyter-notebook" not found'.
It seems that the notebook controller used to be implemented in metacontroller and jsonnet. I think that the controller <denchmark-link:https://github.com/kubeflow/kubeflow/blob/4b1ae00a997cd83b114c5b00d53a0928cdbcb81c/kubeflow/jupyter/jupyter.libsonnet#L344>used to create it</denchmark-link> but in Go it's probably not yet implemented. cc <denchmark-link:https://github.com/lluunn>@lluunn</denchmark-link> <denchmark-link:https://github.com/kunmingg>@kunmingg</denchmark-link>

It should be the kubeflow namespace. I will confirm tomorrow!

<denchmark-link:https://github.com/yanniszark>@yanniszark</denchmark-link>

We no longer use jupyter-notebook serviceaccount for notebooks (see <denchmark-link:https://github.com/kubeflow/kubeflow/pull/3161>#3161</denchmark-link>
)
Also notebook controller image is not up-to-date in master. if you are going to use istio, you hav to build the image first and then use it (/cc <denchmark-link:https://github.com/gabrielwen>@gabrielwen</denchmark-link>
). My pr resolves this (<denchmark-link:https://github.com/kubeflow/kubeflow/pull/3245>#3245</denchmark-link>
)
